text: Welcome to the world of organic farming. Discover sustainable practices, nurturing soil health, and cultivating a greener tomorrow. Organic farming. Modern organic farming originated in the early 20th century as a response to the environmental harm caused by the use of chemical pesticides and synthetic fertilizers in conventional agriculture. Organic farming has numerous ecological benefits. Organic farming, a sustainable agricultural system which avoids or largely excludes the use of synthetic inputs such as fertilizers, pesticides, hormones, feed additives, and to the maximum extent feasible rely upon crop rotations, crop residues, animal manures, off-farm organic waste, mineral grade rock additives, and biological system of nutrient mobilization and plant protection. Its primary objective is to cultivate the land and raise crops in a way that keeps the soil healthy and alive. Need of organic farming. The scientists have realized that the agrene revolution with high input use has reached a plateau. Excessive use of chemical fertilizers reduces the fertility of soil. Excessive use of chemicals has led to soil, water, and air pollution to conserve ecosystem and promote sustainable development. Organic farming is an inexpensive farming. Increased demand of organic products due to safety of food. Agrochemicals derived from fossil fuels are non-renewable and becoming scarce, which could cost us heavily in the future. The obvious choice for that would be more relevant in the present era is organic farming. It focuses on protecting soil fertility, providing crop nutrients naturally, and controlling pests with eco-friendly methods. It also emphasizes responsible livestock management and environmental conservation. Organic farming methods accord with the four basic principles that reveal their essence. Health, ecology, fairness, and care. Techniques in organic farming. Organic farming involves a set of practices and principles designed to maintain and enhance soil fertility, promote biodiversity, and avoid the use of synthetic chemicals. Crop rotation planting different crops in a sequential order on the same piece of land helps prevent the buildup of specific pests and diseases. It also enhances nutrient diversity in the soil. Green manure, a quick growing crop such as sun hemp, crotallaria juncea is cultivated and plowed under to incorporate it into the soil for the purpose of improving its physical structure and fertility. It also increases moisture levels and adds nutrients for microorganisms. Cover cropping this farming approach implies covering the field with any plant species, either for a certain season or perennially, partially between the crop rows or completely. Cover crops tackle soil erosion, improve water filtration, aeration with their roots. Compost, it is the material that results when recycled plant wastes, bio solids, fish, and other organic materials decompose aerobically through the action of microorganisms that live in the presence of air. It is rich in nutrients and helps improve soil structure and water retention. Mulching it is an eco-friendly agricultural practice that improves the overall health of the soil. In organic farming, the land is covered with a layer of natural organic mulch such as straw, crop residue, compost, dry leaves, grass, or manure. Only dried organic matter is used for this purpose as green vegetation needs a long period to decompose, eventually causing pests and fungus. As the mulch retains moisture in the soil, it is helpful for commercial crop production in hot and dry areas. Polyculture growing a variety of crops in the same area mimics natural ecosystems reduces the risk of pest and disease outbreaks, enhances biodiversity and helps to produce necessary soil microorganisms to boost up the production. Genetic modification. We should keep genetic modification away from the field of organic farming. Organic farming emphasizes the use of non-genetically modified, non-GMO, seeds, and traditional breeding methods. Integrated pest management. Organic farming does not intend to destroy them completely as it will cause ecosystem changes. This concept of agriculture strongly relies on the alternative methods of pest control. Prevention. Constructing natural barriers. Physical removal of pests. And tackling pest invasions with their biological enemies predators like ladybugs versus aphids. Integrated weed management. Mechanical method. Mechanical weeders include cultivating tools such as hose, harrows, tines and brush weeders, cutting tools like mowers and stimulus, and dual-purpose implements like thistle bars. Biological method includes allopathy, use of biocontrol agents for weed control, use of competitive plants for weed control. Thermal method includes, flamers, soil solarization, infrared weeders, freezing methods. The biggest challenges in organic farming. Identifying and switching to natural inputs. Ensuring quality and quantity of outputs. Step-by-step guide to organic farming. Learn about organic farming principles, practices, and the requirements for certification. Familiarize yourself with local and national organic farming standards. Identify the crops suitable for organic production in your region. Site selection. Choose a location with suitable soil, climate, and water availability for the crops you plan to grow. Soil test and improvement. Conduct a thorough soil analysis to understand nutrient levels and pH. Gradually reduce reliance on synthetic fertilizers and pesticides. Incorporate organic soil amendments such as compost, green manure, and cover crops to improve soil structure and fertility. Water conservation. Implement water-efficient irrigation methods such as drip irrigation or rainwater harvesting. Moult around plants to conserve soil moisture, suppress weeds, and regulate soil temperature. Employ water conservation practices to minimize water usage. Livestock integration. Manage livestock waste as a manure, a resource for composting and soil enrichment. Follow organic standards for livestock care and feeding. Record keeping. Maintain detailed records of the transition process, inputs used, and farming practices. This documentation is crucial for the organic certification process. Market access and branding. Develop a marketing strategy for your organic products. Communicate the transition to organic farming to consumers through labeling and branding. Engage with the organic community. Connect with local organic farming networks and organizations. Overall, organic farming a significant and expanding industry that has a potential to support environmentally friendly and sustainable agriculture. There may be new chances for farmers and related companies to profit from this expanding trend towards sustainable agriculture as a demand for organic produce rises. While organic farming offers numerous benefits, challenges include lower yields compared to conventional methods. The growing interest in sustainable, healthy food options positions organic farming as a key player in shaping the future of agriculture. Thank you so much for tuning in today. If you found this video helpful or inspiring, don't forget to give it a thumbs up.
